courses.aims:
Students completing the BSc (Hons) in Computer Science will
  • Acquire a general knowledge and understanding of computers and computer science
  • Develop a more specialised knowledge of the theoretical foundation of computer science and other selected topics within the discipline
  • Encounter and work with a variety of approaches, techniques and tools in order to solve the different types of problems encountered in the discipline
  • Acquire the ability to communicate effectively orally and in writing both under pressure and reflectively
  • Understand the professional, legal and ethical aspects of the discipline and know how to act on these appropriately.

c.title: Introduction to Software Engineering & Object-Oriented Programming

courses.title: Bachelor of Science with Honours Computer Science

courses.aims:
You will graduate with
  • an understanding of computers and computer science;
  • knowledge of the theoretical foundations of computer science and other selected topics within the discipline;
  • experience in a variety of techniques needed to solve problems encountered in the discipline;
  • and an understanding of the professional, legal, and ethical aspects of the discipline.

o.title: Methods for Understanding Users in Computer Science

c.title: Introduction to Software Engineering & Object-Oriented Programming

courses.title: Master in Science with Honours Computer Science

courses.aims:
Students completing the BSc (Hons) in Computer Science with Artificial Intelligence will:
  • Acquire a general knowledge and understanding of computers and computer science
  • Develop a more specialised knowledge of theoretical and practical aspects of artificial intelligence
  • Encounter and work with a variety of approaches, techniques and tools in order to solve the different types of problem encountered in computer science in general and artificial intelligence in particular
  • Acquire the ability to communicate effectively orally, and in writing, both under pressure and reflectively
  • Understand the professional, legal, and ethical aspects of the discipline and know how to act on these appropriately

c.title: Introduction to Software Engineering & Object-Oriented Programming

courses.title: Bachelor of Science with Honours Computer Science with Artificial Intelligence

courses.aims:
You will graduate with
  • an understanding of computers, computer science and artificial intelligence;
  • knowledge of the theoretical foundations of computer science;
  • knowledge of the theory, techniques, and applications of artificial intelligence;
  • experience in a variety of techniques needed to solve problems encountered in computer science in general and artificial intelligence in particular; and
  • an understanding of the professional, legal, and ethical aspects of the discipline.

o.title: Methods for Understanding Users in Computer Science

c.title: Introduction to Software Engineering & Object-Oriented Programming

courses.title: Master in Science with Honours Computer Science with Artificial Intelligence

courses.aims:
Students completing the BSc (Hons) in Software Engineering will:
  • Acquire a general knowledge and understanding of computers and software engineering
  • Develop more specialised knowledge of the design, implementation, user interfaces, and evaluation of software engineering
  • Encounter and work with a variety of tools and methodologies in order to solve a variety of problems encountered in the area of software engineering
  • Develop the ability to communicate effectively orally and in writing in a variety of situations

c.title: Introduction to Software Engineering & Object-Oriented Programming

courses.title: Bachelor of Science with Honours Software Engineering

courses.aims:
Students completing the BSc (Hons) in Computer Science and Management Studies will
  • Acquire a general knowledge and understanding of computers, computer science and management studies
  • Develop a more specialised knowledge of selected topics within the disciplines, with particular focus on the management of information and other resources.
  • Encounter and work with a variety of approaches, techniques and tools in order to solve the different types of problem encountered in the disciplines.
  • Acquire the ability to communicate effectively orally and in writing both under pressure and reflectively
  • Understand the professional, legal and ethical aspects of the discipline and know how to act on these appropriately.
  • Gain an understanding of organisations, their management and the changing external environment in which they operate.

o.title: Introduction to Management Science for Business Decisions

c.title: Introduction to Software Engineering & Object-Oriented Programming

courses.title: Bachelor of Science with Joint Honours Computer Science and Management Studies

courses.aims:
The programme aims to provide the students with the opportunity to:
  • build the information data structure in network and distributed computing systems, by using computer tools of different strengths and weakness;
  • understand complex ideas, logically evaluate system requirements, systematically analyse information, and apply IT management methodologies;
  • understand the issues and factors related to the planning of projects, and apply IT methodologies in computer systems;
  • apply software engineering methodologies to construct systems.

o.title: Methods for Understanding Users in Computer Science

courses.title: Master of Science Information Technology

courses.aims:
The programme aims to provide the students with the opportunity to:
  • understand the data and information structure in building computing systems, using computer tools of different strengths and weakness;
  • understand complex ideas, logically evaluate system requirements, systematically analyse information, and apply IT management methodologies;
  • understand the issues and factors related to the planning of projects, and the management of IT in computer systems.

c.title: Project in the Management of Information Technology

o.title: Methods for Understanding Users in Computer Science

courses.title: Master of Science Management of Information Technology

courses.aims: The aim of this degree is to properly reflect the full range of research of the School in its Masters degree programmes. The degree will train scientists and engineers in advanced computational techniques (specifically algorithmics and advanced programming) and the relevant scientific basis (correct-by-construction program design, foundations of artificial intelligence and program analysis). It will prepare students for highly skilled careers in industry and/or research. The degree will be open to all computer science graduates, including those from the University of Nottingham. It may provide teaching support for research students in the School. (These will be allowed to follow individual modules. in whole or in part, although not being formally registered for the degree.)

o.title: Methods for Understanding Users in Computer Science

courses.title: Master of Science Advanced Computing Science

courses.aims:
The aims of the MSc in Computer Science and Entrepreneurship are to provide students with the opportunity to:
  • critically review state-of-the-art research advances to develop ideas in market for entrepreneurs;
  • identify commercial potentials based on recent advances and best practice;
  • transfer computing technologies in development of information technologies and computer science research.
courses.title: Master of Science Computer Science and Entrepreneurship

courses.aims:
The aims of the MSc in Human Computer Interaction are to provide students with the opportunity to:
  • Develop detailed knowledge of the necessary theory and practice required to design, evaluate and implement interactive computing systems;
  • Initiate careers where the requirements of people are central to the design philosophy (e.g. as a usability engineer/manager, user-interface designer, information systems architect);
  • Enhance skills and knowledge, as prospective/current software engineers;
  • Develop appropriate skills and knowledge as a basis for research work, e.g. as part of a PhD programme;
  • Develop critical and analytical skills relevant to the practice of Human Computer Interaction;
  • Enhance their ability to communicate effectively orally and in writing, both under pressure and reflectively;
  • Enhance their abilities to work both independently and in a team.

c.title: Contemporary Issues in Human Factors & Interactive Systems

o.title: Methods for Understanding Users in Computer Science

courses.title: Master of Science Human Computer Interaction
